abstract_sentences.1: Text similarity measures are used in multiple tasks such as plagiarism detection, information ranking and recognition of paraphrases and textual entailment.
abstract_sentences.2: While recent advances in deep learning highlighted further the relevance of sequential models in natural language generation, existing similarity measures do not fully exploit the sequential nature of language.
abstract_sentences.3: Examples of such similarity measures include ngrams and skip-grams overlap which rely on distinct slices of the input texts.
abstract_sentences.4: In this paper we present a novel text similarity measure inspired from a common representation in DNA sequence alignment algorithms.
abstract_sentences.5: The new measure, called TextFlow, represents input text pairs as continuous curves and uses both the actual position of the words and sequence matching to compute the similarity value.
abstract_sentences.6: Our experiments on eight different datasets show very encouraging results in paraphrase detection, textual entailment recognition and ranking relevance.

body_sentences.2: While a big part of this content consists of visual information such as pictures and videos, texts also continue growing at a very high pace.
body_sentences.3: A recent study shows that the average webpage weights 1,200 KB with plain text accounting for up to 16% of that size2.

body_sentences.5: These tasks are also often performed on dedicated document collections for domain-specific applications where text similarity measures can be directly applied.
body_sentences.6: Finding relevant approaches to compute text similarity motivated a lot of research in the last decades (Sahami and Heilman, 2006; Hatzivassiloglou et al., 1999), and more recently with deep learning methods (Socher et al., 2011; Yih et al., 2011; Severyn and Moschitti, 2015).
body_sentences.7: However, most of the recent advances focused on designing high performance classification methods, trained and tested for specific tasks and did not offer a standalone similarity measure that could be applied (i) regardless of the application domain and (ii) without requiring training corpora.
body_sentences.8: For instance, Yih and Meek (2007) presented an approach to improve text similarity measures for web search queries with a length ranging from one word to short sequences of words.
body_sentences.9: The proposed method is tailored to this specific task, and the training models are not expected to perform well on different kinds of data such as sentences, questions or paragraphs.
body_sentences.10: In a more general study, Achananuparp et al.
body_sentences.11: (2008) compared several text similarity measures for paraphrase recognition, textual entailment, and the TREC 9 question variants task.
body_sentences.12: In their experiments the best performance was obtained with a linear combination of semantic and lexical similarities, including a word order similarity proposed in (Li et al., 2006).
body_sentences.13:
This word order similarity is computed by constructing first two vectors representing the common words between two given sentences and using their respective positions in the sentences as term

body_sentences.14: The similarity value is then obtained by subtracting the two vectors and taking the absolute value.
body_sentences.15: While such representation takes into account the actual positions of the words, it does not allow detecting sub-sequence matches and takes into account missing words only by omission.
body_sentences.16: More generally, existing standalone (or traditional) text similarity measures rely on the intersections between token sets and/or text sizes and frequency, including measures such as the Cosine similarity, Euclidean distance, Levenshtein (Sankoff and Kruskal, 1983), Jaccard (Jain and Dubes, 1988) and Jaro (Jaro, 1989).
body_sentences.17: The sequential nature of natural language is taken into account mostly through word n-grams and skipgrams which capture distinct slices of the analysed texts but do not preserve the order in which they appear.
body_sentences.18: In this paper, we use intuitions from a common representation in DNA sequence alignment to design a new standalone similarity measure called TextFlow (XF).
body_sentences.19: The proposed measure uses at the same time the full sequence of input texts in a natural sub-sequence matching approach together with individual token matches and mismatches.
body_sentences.20:
Our contributions can be detailed further as follows:
• A novel standalone similarity measure which:
– exploits the full sequence of words in the compared texts.
body_sentences.21: – is asymmetric in a way that allows it to provide the best performance on different tasks (e.g., paraphrase detection, textual entailment and ranking).
body_sentences.22: – when required, it can be trained with a small set of parameters controlling the impact of sub-sequence matching, position gaps and unmatched words.
body_sentences.23: – provides consistent high performance across tasks and datasets compared to traditional similarity measures.
body_sentences.24: • A neural network architecture to train TextFlow parameters for specific tasks.
body_sentences.25: • An empirical study on both performance consistency and standard evaluation measures, performed with eight datasets from three different tasks.
body_sentences.26: • A new evaluation measure, called CORE, used to better show the consistency of a system at high performance using both its rank average and rank variance when compared to competing systems over a set of datasets.

2 The TextFlow Similarity
XF is inspired from a dot matrix representation commonly used in pairwise DNA sequence alignment (cf.
body_sentences.29: We use a similar dot matrix representation for text pairs and draw a curve oscillating around the diagonal (cf.
body_sentences.31: The area under the curve is considered to be the distance between the two text pairs which is then normalized with the matrix surface.
body_sentences.32: For practical computation, we transform this first intuitive representation using the delta of positions as in figure 3.
body_sentences.33: In this setting, the Y axis is the delta of positions of a word occurring in the two texts being compared.
body_sentences.34: If the word does not occur in the target text, the delta is considered to be a maximum reference value (l in figure 2).
body_sentences.35: The semantics are: the bigger the area under curve is, the lower the similarity between the compared texts.
body_sentences.36: XF values are real numbers in the [0,1] interval, with 1 indicating a perfect match, and 0 indicating that the compared texts do not have any common tokens.
body_sentences.37: With this representation, we are able to take into account all matched words and sub-sequences at the same time.

This evaluation was performed on 8 datasets from 3 different classification tasks: Tex-
tual Entailment Recognition, Paraphrase Detection, and ranking relevance.
body_sentences.60:
The datasets are as follows:
• RTE 1, 2, and 3: the first three datasets from the Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE) challenge (Dagan et al., 2006).
body_sentences.61: Each dataset consists of sentence pairs which are annotated with 2 labels: entailment, and nonentailment.
body_sentences.62: They contain respectively (200, 800), (800, 800), and (800, 800) (train, test) pairs.
body_sentences.63: • Guardian: an RTE dataset collected from 78,696 Guardian articles5 published from January 2004 onwards and consisting of 32K pairs which we split randomly in 90%/10% training/test sets.
body_sentences.64: Positive examples were collected from the titles and first sentences.
body_sentences.65: Negative examples were collected from the same source by selecting consecutive sentences and random sentences.
body_sentences.66:
• SNLI: a recent RTE dataset consisting of 560K training sentence pairs annotated with

body_sentences.69: • MSRP: the Microsoft Research Paraphrase corpus, consisting of 5,800 sentence pairs annotated with a binary label indicating whether the two sentences are paraphrases or not.
body_sentences.70: • Semeval-16-3B: a dataset of questionquestion similarity collected from StackOverflow (Nakov et al., 2016).
body_sentences.71: The dataset contains 3,169 training pairs and 700 test pairs.
body_sentences.72: Three labels are considered: ”Perfect Match”, ”Relevant” or ”Irrelevant”.
body_sentences.73: We combined the first two into the same positive category for our evaluation.
body_sentences.74: • Semeval-14-1: a corpus of Sentences Involving Compositional Knowledge (Marelli et al., 2014) consisting of 10,000 English sentence pairs annotated with both similarity scores and relevance labels.

body_sentences.104: 4.2 Trained Text Flow  When compared to state-of-the-art measures and to canonical XF, the trained version, XFt, obtained the best accuracy with a gap ranging from +1.4 to +7.8.
body_sentences.105: XFt also obtained the second best F1 average with a -1.0 gap, but with clear inconsistencies according to the dataset.
body_sentences.106: XFt obtained the best precision with a gap ranging from +0.8 to +7.1.
body_sentences.107: XFt did not perform well on recall with 64.5% micro-average compared to WordOverlap with 72%.
body_sentences.108: Both its recall and F1 performance can be explained by the fact that the measure was trained to optimize accuracy, and not the F1 score for the positive class; which also suggests that the approach could be adapted to F1 optimization if needed.
body_sentences.109: 4.3 Synthesis  Canonical XF was more consistent than trained XF on all dimensions except accuracy, for which XFt was optimized.
body_sentences.110: We argue that this consistency was made possible through the asymmetry of XF which allowed it to adapt to different kinds of similarities (i.e., equivalence/paraphrase, inference/entailment, and mutual distance/ranking).
body_sentences.111: These results also show that the actual position difference is a relevant factor for text similarity.

body_sentences.128: 5 Conclusion  We presented a novel standalone similarity measure that takes into account continuous word sequences.
body_sentences.129: An evaluation on eight datasets show promising results for textual entailment recognition, paraphrase detection and ranking.
body_sentences.130: Among the potential extensions of this work are the inclusion of different kinds of weights such as TF-IDF, embedding relatedness and semantic relatedness.
body_sentences.131: We also intend to test other variants around the same concept, including considering the matched words and sequences to have a negative weight to balance further the weight of missing words.
